awd_titl_txt: High-Resolution Laser Diagnostics and Modeling of Single-Walled Carbon Nanotube Synthesis by Plasma-Enhanced CVD
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET-0828165
Lucht

This research aims to develop key science for developing controlled synthesis of single-wall carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) by plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD).  Carbon nanotubes have been shown to produce a wide range of outstanding physical properties with important technical and societal implications. However, some crucial properties depend strongly on material parameters that, to date, have been largely uncontrollable in the synthesis process. 

Well controlled fabrication of carbon nanotubes could enable breakthroughs across a vast range of applications, including ultrafast field-effect transistors and nanoelectronic circuits, direct energy-conversion processes, field-emission devices, high-temperature superconductors, textile fibers, and high-thermal-conductivity films. In addition, the microwave plasma has potentially very high concentrations of species such as CH3 and C-atom. These species are very important in combustion chemistry, but diagnostic techniques for these species are not well developed. The H2/CH4 plasma is thus of great interest as a testbed for the development of new optical diagnostic techniques.

A technique pioneered by the research team aids synthesis by reducing concentration of atomic hydrogen from the growth surface, where they etch SWCNTs even at room temperature. The key is applying a positive electrical bias to the growth surface to repel H+ ions from it. Although the role of atomic H appears to be critical in these new processes, very little is known about the composition of the plasma near the growth surface. Spatially resolved optical measurements and complementary models, to be applied and developed in this work, are critical to understanding the role of species such as atomic H and carbon-containing precursors to CNT synthesis. The knowledge gained in this work is expected to enable the creation of synthesis protocols and models that in turn will aid the longer-term goal of controlled synthesis of CNT materials, structures, and devices. 

The proposed program will expose mechanical engineering graduate students to additional areas of science and engineering, such as molecular electronics and plasma physics, through existing collaborations with electrical engineers, material scientists, physicists, and chemists. In addition, exciting new research on nanotechnology and laser diagnostics will strongly attract domestic students into science and technology research careers through participation in Purdue's Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship (SURF) program.

Although various studies have been conducted and simulations created exploring the chemical kinetics of the environment in chemical vapor deposition and plasma-assisted chemical vapor deposition (PACVD) reactors, few studies have focused on highly spatially resolved investigations of the plasma sheath and presheath region near the boundary of a substrate and plasma bulk in a microwave plasma chemical vapor deposition (MPCVD) reactor. A MPCVD system differs from a PACVD system primarily in that the source of the plasma is a microwave generator playing a vital role in the synthesis mechanism of the carbon nanostructures. The MPCVD system is illustrated schemcatically in Fig. 1.

In order to exploit the extraordinary properties of the potential technological applications of carbon nanostructures an improved understanding of the chemical environment responsible for their synthesis is crucial. The spatial distribution of the rotational temperature of molecular hydrogen is investigated via coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering (CARS) spectroscopy in the plasma of a MPCVD reactor under parametrically controlled conditions. The reactor pressure is varied from 10 to 30 Torr and the plasma generator power from 300 to 700 W, simulating the conditions required for the synthesis of carbon nanotubes, graphene and graphitic nanopetals. In addition, methane and nitrogen are introduced into the reactor so as to investigate their effect on the rotational temperature of hydrogen. Temperature measurements are conducted within the plasma sheath at 2 mm and up to 6 mm away from the puck surface in order to elucidate the spatial distribution of temperature within and around the plasma region.

The hydrogen plasma is generated by applying a strong electromagnetic field via a microwave generator to a flow of molecular hydrogen at 50 sccm. The microwaves couple with a molybdenum puck on which substrates for synthesis are placed. CARS spectroscopy is a highly spatially resolved, nonintrusive optical technique whereby the Raman polarization of the molecule under investigation is pumped and scattered by three coherent beams. The CARS phase-matching arrangement is shown in Fig. 2. Upon converging within the plasma, a coherent  beam is generated from the probe volume and collected and analyzed via a spectrometer and CCD camera system.  A theoretical spectrum is generated and parameters including the hydrogen rotational temperature are varied until a best fit is obtained between theory and experiment.  A typical experimental and best-fit theoretical spectrum are shown in Fig. 3.

Temperature profiles in the MPCVD reactor are shown in Figs. 4-6.  At 10 Torr, the temperature range is 700 – 1200 K increasing with distance normal to the puck surface, plasma generator power from 300 to 500 W and the introduction of methane at 10 sccm. Likewise, temperature increases with distance, generator power from 500 to 700 W and introduction of methane at 30 Torr although the range is higher, 1200 – 2000 K. Finally, the rotational temperature of hydrogen is shown to increase with the introduction of nitrogen at 5 sccm into the hydrogen plasma and more so when methane at 10 sccm is introduced in addition to nitrogen by 100 K.

The increase in temperature with generator power and reactor pressure can be qualitatively explained due to the increase in energy per unit volume in the plasma bulk leading to more heavily excited electrons and their energy exchange with ions and neutrals. The increase in temperature with the introduction of heavier species such as methane and nitrogen is qualitatively explained by the increase in momentum-energy transfer among neutrals.
